abstracts.cdata!:
The Nutrition Project for Ethiopia was
            rated satisfactory with moderate risk to development
            outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrowers performances were
            rated moderately satisfactory. The project was restructured
            on April 2, 2012 to refine the results framework, some
            indicators to allow more rigorous and timely monitoring of
            the project, and baselines. It was restructured again
            December 16, 2013, to extend the grant closing date by 5
            months. Additionally, one new PDO indicator was added
            (Growth Monitoring and Promotion GMP sessions) with the
            existing iodized salt indicator removed. As for the
            intermediary indicators, two new indicators were included
            (health personnel receiving training in CBN and masters
            level training in nutrition) and others were refined in
            their specificity. There were several lessons learned from
            this project including the following: (1) strong country
            ownership and integration of interventions into an existing
            and wider multi sectoral agenda on nutrition and
            multi-partner investment strategy was key to the success of
            the project, (2) the existence of an existing
            institutionalized community level service delivery model,
            quite unique to Ethiopia, was instrumental to the success of
            the project at the community level, and (3) multi-sectoral
            coordination on nutrition is difficult, yet critical to the
            achievement of the wider nutrition agenda of countries.
